results.abstract: The “Curb Your Enthusiasm” actress is beloved in Hollywood. In supporting her husband’s campaign, is she normalizing his often dangerous ideas?
org_facet: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

media.caption: “I support Bobby and I want to be there for him, and I want him to feel loved and supported by me,” said Cheryl Hines, who was photographed at her home in Los Angeles. “And at the same time, I don’t feel the need to go to every political event, because I do have my own career.”

results.abstract: The irascible rocker, now 71, reflects on how America plays into his music, his relationship to his biggest hits and his latest album, “Orpheus Descending.”

results.title: Why You Can’t Really Be a Gardener Without Mindfulness
results.abstract: In the last volume of his memoir trilogy, Marc Hamer explains why a garden is not just a place of work — it’s also a place of worship.

media.caption: As a gardener, Marc Hamer said, you “are very much aware that your existence is for a very short period of time, and that you are just like the plants are, rising and blooming, and then fading.”

results.byline: By Matt Richtel and David Williams
results.title: The Refries That Bind: A Cavernous Cantina Returns, Cliff Divers and All
results.abstract: With “infinity dollars” poured in by the creators of “South Park,” a fabled Colorado restaurant reopens with the same 1970s vibe and drastically improved food.

media.caption: The refurbished Casa Bonita, a beloved, and mocked, Colorado institution. The 56,000-square-foot Mexican restaurant went bankrupt during the pandemic but was rescued by new owners, Trey Parker and Matt Stone of “South Park” fame.
